update.description:
A plugin for the swarm project. This plugin will apply a random velocity, given some constraints, to a link in a model. We will be using this to produce a simple random walk.

[No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/543)

[nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/419)

[Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/420)
update.title: Random velocity plugin

content.raw: Thanks, merged.
content.html: Thanks, merged.

content.raw: The velocities will stop updating after a world reset for a fixed period of time since the `prevUpdate` field does not get reset. I made a fix in 1f6c02c (branch `gazebo6_random_vel_reset`)
content.html: The velocities will stop updating after a world reset for a fixed period of time since the prevUpdate field does not get reset. I made a fix in 1f6c02c (branch gazebo6_random_vel_reset)

content.raw: fixed a copy/paste error in 13e6e4d457ef
content.html: fixed a copy/paste error in 13e6e4d457ef

update.title: Random velocity plugin

content.raw: Yeah, I was valuing clamping over `velocity_factor`. I could add another parameter to the plugin so that the behavior can be changed.
content.html: Yeah, I was valuing clamping over velocity_factor. I could add another parameter to the plugin so that the behavior can be changed.

content.raw: I'll approve after the min <= max fix
content.html: I'll approve after the min <= max fix

content.raw:
If we want to prioritize clamping over the `velocity_factor`, then the current implementation does that.

Since the parameters are potentially conflicting, I just wanted to be clear about their relative priority
content.html:
If we want to prioritize clamping over the velocity_factor, then the current implementation does that.

Since the parameters are potentially conflicting, I just wanted to be clear about their relative priority

content.raw:
My gut tells me we should:

1. Use unclamped values if no clamping is specified.
2. Use clamped values if clamping is specified (inequality clamping)
     - I currently don't check to make sure min <= max, which I'm fixing now.

We might be getting into the weeds though.
content.html:
My gut tells me we should:

  1. Use unclamped values if no clamping is specified.
  2. Use clamped values if clamping is specified (inequality clamping)
    • I currently don't check to make sure min <= max, which I'm fixing now.

We might be getting into the weeds though.

content.raw:
My original comment was based on the example in `worlds/random_velocity.world`, which has two unclamped variables and one clamped to zero.

Also, there could be a fight between parameters if the `velocity_factor` is smaller than the minimum of a parameter (ie. velocity_factor=0.1, min_x=1)
content.html:
My original comment was based on the example in worlds/random_velocity.world, which has two unclamped variables and one clamped to zero.

Also, there could be a fight between parameters if the velocity_factor is smaller than the minimum of a parameter (ie. velocity_factor=0.1, min_x=1)

content.raw: Thanks, I missed that
content.html: Thanks, I missed that

content.raw:
Well I guess there's a few different cases for each variable:

* unclamped (min, max not specified)
* unilateral clamping (one of min or max specified)
* equality clamping (min = max)
* inequality clamping (min < max and both are finite)

Which cases are most important to us?
content.html:
Well I guess there's a few different cases for each variable:

  • unclamped (min, max not specified)
  • unilateral clamping (one of min or max specified)
  • equality clamping (min = max)
  • inequality clamping (min < max and both are finite)

Which cases are most important to us?

content.raw: Kind of hidden. Check out line 35 in `RandomVelocityPluginPrivate.hh` below.
content.html: Kind of hidden. Check out line 35 in RandomVelocityPluginPrivate.hh below.

content.raw: otherwise won't everything clamp to zero?
content.html: otherwise won't everything clamp to zero?

content.raw: Should the [xyz]Range values be initialized to [-Inf, Inf]?
content.html: Should the [xyz]Range values be initialized to [-Inf, Inf]?

content.raw:
Right, I think I remember. If we normalize and scale after the clamp, then it's possible for the new values to fall outside the clamp boundaries.

Here is an example:

* scale = 1
* x-min = 0
* x-max = 0.1
* no other clamp values

`
rand_velocity_before_clamp = [0.3, 0.7, 0]
rand_velocity_after_clamp = [0.1, 0.7, 0]

rand_velocity_normalized = [0.141421, 0.989949, 0]
`

The result would be a velocity that violates the clamp.
content.html:
Right, I think I remember. If we normalize and scale after the clamp, then it's possible for the new values to fall outside the clamp boundaries.

Here is an example:

  • scale = 1
  • x-min = 0
  • x-max = 0.1
  • no other clamp values

` rand_velocity_before_clamp = [0.3, 0.7, 0] rand_velocity_after_clamp = [0.1, 0.7, 0]

rand_velocity_normalized = [0.141421, 0.989949, 0] `

The result would be a velocity that violates the clamp.

content.raw: Yeah, I went back and forth on this. At the time I had a use-case for leaving the code like this, but now I can't remember. I'll put in the change.
content.html: Yeah, I went back and forth on this. At the time I had a use-case for leaving the code like this, but now I can't remember. I'll put in the change.

content.raw:
I think clamping after normalizing and scaling the velocity can change the velocity magnitude slightly. If we really want the velocity magnitude to match the `velocityFactor`, then we should normalize and scale again after clamping.

I'm not sure how much this matters.
content.html:
I think clamping after normalizing and scaling the velocity can change the velocity magnitude slightly. If we really want the velocity magnitude to match the velocityFactor, then we should normalize and scale again after clamping.

I'm not sure how much this matters.
